basics.name: Tanner Young
basics.label: Student
basics.summary: I am studying for a B.S. in Computer Science in the Department of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Hawaii. I expect to graduate in Spring, 2024.

courses: ICS 241: Discrete Math II for CS
ICS 141: Discrete Math I for CS

work.company: Applied Research Laboratory at the University of Hawaii
work.summary: Worked as computer science assistant under Noah Hafner, PhD
highlights: Conducted a trade study on single board computers as an alternative for the Raspberry Pi Zero
Worked with Protocol Buffers for serializing and transferring structured data using microcontrollers
Gathered, logged, and parsed data from a variety of sensors using Python
Tested a variety of hardware components for compatability with the LSTS toolchain

work.summary: Worked as an intern at the University of Washington under Dr. Chris Hague, PhD
highlights: Conducted research on generating stable cell lines expressing the Somatostatin receptor 2
Collaborated with and learned from a team of graduate students
Used various lab skills to conduct the experiments

work.summary: Worked as an intern at Penn Vet under De'broski R. Herbert, PhD and Yingbiao Ji, PhD
highlights: Conducted research on Trefoil factors and LINGO genes effect on immune response
Worked closely with multiple PhDs and graduate students to further my research
Cited as a coauthor in the completed research paper

volunteer.summary: Helped to teach children in Sunday School
highlights: Worked with groups of younger children
Explained and aided them in understanding the message each week

awards.title: Manoa Academic Merit Scholarship
awards.summary: Scholarship is an automatic $2,000 scholarship per year for four years of undergraduate study for first-time degree seeking students. Students must have a 3.5 GPA, 1200 SAT or 23 ACT upon the time of application to UH Manoa.

awards.title: Dean's List
awards.summary: Undergraduate students are awarded the Dean's List distinction if they: (1) earn a semester grade point average of 3.5 or higher based on 12 credits or more taken for a grade (C/NC courses do not count), and (2) do not receive grades of W, I, F, or NC for that semester.
